chapter.htmlHeader: What else might it be?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Differential diagnoses of superficial vein thrombosis include:
    • Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) — presents with pain and swelling, tenderness, redness and warmth of the skin, and vein distension in one leg. It is distinguished from superficial vein thrombosis by generalized pain and swelling of the leg that is not localized to a thrombosed vein. For more information, see the CKS topic on Deep vein thrombosis.
    • Cellulitis — erythema is usually localized and confluent, with associated tenderness and generalized swelling. There may be associated lymphangitis or tender lymphadenopathy, which is not characteristic of superficial vein thrombosis. A palpable cord is not present with cellulitis. Fever, chill, and myalgia are more common with cellulitis. For more information, see the CKS topic on Cellulitis - acute.
    • Chronic venous insufficiency — usually chronic leg swelling with associated ectatic veins, varicose veins, and skin changes that may include hyperpigmentation, venous eczema, lipodermatosclerosis, and venous ulcers. For more information, see the CKS topics on Venous eczema and lipodermatosclerosis and Leg ulcer - venous.
    • Insect bite or stings — there is usually a recent history of an insect bite or sting. Swelling and redness usually extend over a large area and do not follow the course of a vein. There may be associated pruritus. For more information, see the CKS topics on Insect bites and stings. 
    • Lymphangitis — presents with red streaks from the infected area to the groin or armpit (may be faint or obvious), warmth, enlarged and tender lymph nodes (usually in the elbow, armpit, or groin), and a raised border around the affected area. High fever, chills, and moderate pain and swelling may also occur.
    • Tendonitis — usually pain, mild swelling, and warmth in the area of a tendon. Pain is worse during and after activity, and the tendon and joint area can become stiff as the swelling impinges on the movement of the joint. For more information, see the CKS topics on Achilles tendinopathy and Sprains and strains.
    • Vasculitic conditions (such as erythema nodosum and polyarteritis nodosum) — characterized by inflammation within or around blood vessels, with or without necrosis. Presentation is variable and includes skin signs, such as palpable purpura (often painful) usually on the lower leg/buttock, and systemic signs, such as fever, night sweats, malaise, weight loss, and arthralgia.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: This information is taken from review articles [Cosmi, 2015; BMJ, 2018] and the Oxford Handbook of General Practice [Simon et al, 2010].
